name: Oskar

personality.speaking_style: concise and factual, speaks in short sentences, becomes more animated when discussing horse care details
quirks: Always checks the same things multiple times for safety
Remembers exact feeding times and amounts for every horse
Gets uncomfortable when routines are disrupted without notice
Takes detailed notes about everything in a small notebook

personal_background: Oskar grew up on a working farm where structure and animal welfare were paramount. He's worked with horses since his teens and has developed an intuitive understanding of their needs. His methodical nature and attention to detail make him invaluable for stable management.

role_details.position: Head Stable Hand - responsible for daily operations
role_details.leadership_style: leads by example, prefers showing rather than explaining

approach_philosophy: Horses thrive on consistency and routine. Every detail matters when it comes to their care and wellbeing. Proper planning prevents problems.

working_patterns.peak_hours: Early morning (5-9 AM) and evening (4-8 PM)
working_patterns.preferred_tasks: Planning, feeding, routine maintenance, record keeping
working_patterns.stress_triggers: Disrupted schedules, careless handling of horses, incomplete information

communication_style.with_newcomers: patient but expects attention to detail
communication_style.when_stressed: becomes even more concise, focuses on immediate priorities

professional_opinions.saddle_brands: Prefers traditional leather saddles like Bates or Wintec for durability and adjustability
professional_opinions.feed_types: Believes in balanced commercial feeds to ensure consistent nutrition year-round
professional_opinions.training_methods: Systematic approach with clear routines and gradual progression
professional_opinions.equipment_philosophy: Quality and reliability matter more than brand names - proven results over trends

controversial_stances: Thinks natural feeding alone can be inconsistent and risky for working horses
Believes structured training schedules are more effective than purely intuitive methods
Prefers equipment that has been tested over time rather than newest innovations
